Method:
Cut eggplants in half lengthwise. Place on baking sheet face down and cook in oven on high heat. When thoroughly cooked set aside to cool. When still warm and able to picked up, scoop out the flesh from the eggplant and place in robocoupe. Puree till smooth and add minced garlic and remaining ingredients.

1) Add potatoes to perforated hotel pans and put in rationale oven. Steam potatoes until about 85% done and a knife can be easily inserted into the potatoe with little resistance, about 15-20 minutes.
2) Carefully spread potatoes out on sheet pan to cool. Put on speed racks.
3) IF APPLICABLE---When cool, tear apart by hand in rough chunks. Reserve for making classic potato salad.---- If NOT FOR POTATO SALAD, THERE IS NO NEED TO TEAR THEM UP
4) For service, fry potatoe chunks in 350* fryer until crispy on the outside and cooked throughout, about 4 minutes. Alternatively, roast in 450*F oven until crispy, about 15-20 minutes.
Allergens:
No known priority allergens.

1. Over medium heat in tilt kettle or large rondeau, add oil. Once hot, add onion and saute until beginning to soften, about 5 minutes. Add garlic and saute 1 minute more.
2. Add spices and continue to saute onion until spices are fragrant, about 5 minutes more.
3. Add tomato and lentils and contine sauting until everything is combined.
4. Add veg stock and simmer partially covered for 20-30 minutes until lentils are soft, but not mushy. Season to taste.

***COOKS AND CHEFS, PLEASE READ THE ENTIRE RECIPE BEFORE BEGINNING- THIS IS A RECOMMENDED STEP WITH EVERY PRODUCT WE EVER PRODUCE- THANK YOU*** Related Products this prep gets used in:
Allergens: Method:
1. Cut potatoes in half then steam until tender, about 15 minutes.
2. On medium low heat, add oil to large rondeau. Add cumin seeds and toast until fragrant, 30 seconds to 1 minute. Add onion, coriander, chili powder, turmeric, jalapeno and garam masala. Saute until onion is soft and spices are fragrant.
3. Add garlic and ginger and saute for 1 minute more.
4. Add tomato paste and saute for 4 minute. Add diced tomatoes and saute 1 minute more.
5. Add fenugreek, lime juice and fresh coriander and stir well to combine.
6. Adjust seasoning.
7. NOTE: Add cooked potatoes and cauliflower during REHEATING for service for best results.
8. Stir well to combine.

***COOKS AND CHEFS, PLEASE READ THE ENTIRE RECIPE BEFORE BEGINNING- THIS IS A RECOMMENDED STEP WITH EVERY PRODUCT WE EVER PRODUCE- THANK YOU*** Amanda
Related Products this prep gets used in:
Allergens: Method:
1. Zest and juice your 2 lemons.
2. Finely chop dill.
3. Process Cucumbers. These should be pulsed in the RoboCoupe. PULSED - NOT LEFT ON TO BECOME A SOUP. What you want is something about the consistency of a small dice. When this is done, transfer this mixture into a bowl with Cheese Cloth. RING OUT AS MUCH WATER AS YOU CAN. THIS WATER IS DELICIOUS. I RECOMMEND DRINKING IT FOR ITS ELECTROLYTE PROPERTIES. Unfortunately, it just doesn't belong in the Yoghurt in this recipe, as it would turn into Cacic.
4. Combine lemon juice and garlic. Let sit for 10 minutes. Salt this mixture to "cook out" the garlic as much as possible.
5. Fold all ingredients into one another. Taste for Salinity, Acidity, and add honey if the Sweetness needs a little kick.
-cool, store, label and rotate this item with older product correctly and diligently.
Portioning:
Utensils needed:
NOTES: It's important to note that this is an opportunity for using old or slightly old Cucumber! For instance: look at the recipe for Taboulleh Salad Mix - Cucumber cores should be saved, and then processed and strained in Cheese Cloth for this recipe - otherwise it will be too watery.
In Turkey, there is a dish known as Cacic - a watery version of Tzatziki. The ingredients are more or less the same. What we know as Tzatziki is actually made with Labneh, which is pressed Yoghurt. Since we use regular Yoghurt in this recipe, we have to limit the amount of water content in it, otherwise it will be an undesirable AND low-quality product.

Method:
1) Over medium/ low heat in large rondeau, add oil, cinnamon and onions and cook till nearly carmalized and golden brown.
2) Add ginger, garlic, seeded jalapenos and cook until peppers are soft.
3) Add tomato paste and cook, stirring often until it is a deep, dark brown.
4) Add ground dry spices and vindaloo paste and cook for 10 minutes, or until spice is cooked out. Taste to ensure that the spices are cooked out.
5) Add water, diced tomatoes and juice, salt, lemon juice and brown sugar. Bring to a simmer. Allow to simmer for 10 minutes.
6) Remove from heat, remove cinnamon sticks. Puree with immersion blender.

ALLERGENS: MUSTARD
Prep:
1. Clean and cut Potatoes into large uniform shapes and sizes. Each Potato may yield 6 pieces, if cut properly - about the same style as Homestyle Potatoes. Steam these in the combi oven until soft but not crumbling apart - use the steam setting: check after 30 minutes.
2. Cut the Cauliflower into florets, and deep fry until golden brown - then set aside. Rough Chop Onions, and set aside your Ginger and Garlic. While you're doing this, set aside your spices - to be used at the beginning of the cooking process. Also, set aside your 4 litres of Water (though, it may not be necessary).
5. In the Tilt Skillet, starting with Canola Oil - start to saute your onions (towards caramelized). Then, throw in your spices, and saute them as well - before adding your Garlic and Ginger.
6. As soon as you add your Garlic and Ginger, you're going to want to deglaze the Tilt Skillet by adding up to 3 litres of the water you set aside. At this point you can add your Turmeric, Garam Masala, Mustard, and canned Tomatoes.
7. Let simmer for a few minutes before adding the fried Cauliflower, and Potatoes. Turn up the heat on the skillet at this point, and scrape the bottom of the skillet with the mixing paddle to accumulate caramelized sugars therein that will burn if left unincorporated. Use the remaining water in this recipe, or more, if need be - keep it moving! You're near the end here.
8. Turn the temperature down on the Tilt Skillet. Rough Chop the Cilantro and Mint. Cut the Serrano Peppers thinly on a mandoline, and then throw all of these ingredients into the mixture.
9. Season to taste at this point - the salt in this recipe is roughly 1.2% of recipe weight. You may find that you need more.
10. Finish with lime juice before serving. This could change depending on how you're doing your batches - but the finished product should be given acidity with lime juice prior to serving regardless of how this dish interacts with the Hot Holds.
Any questions - Ask Chef!

ALLERGENS: MUSTARD
Prep:
- Weigh out all ingredients. - Set aside Sugar and Salt.
- Toast all Spices / Seeds, until fragrant. This would be done at a higher heat that the next step. - Toast Split Peas separately - low heat.
- Mix all ingredients together, and take to the Vitamix. Grind into a fine powder.
Label / Date / Store Appropriately.
Note: when cooking with this, it's important to fry out the Split Pea in this recipe. It cannot be used simply as a spice mix like others - Baharat (which just means Spice in Turkish and a few other Middle Eastern dialects), Ras Al Hanout, etc. - it needs to be partially cooked. This does wonders for the spice elements. But, it also takes the grainy-ness out of the Split Peas (important).
Any questions, Ask Chef!

ALLERGENS: WHEAT, GLUTEN
Prep:
- Take the Coriander Seeds, Cumin Seeds, Ajwain Seeds, Black Pepper and Garam Masala - and toast, then grind in the Vitamix into a fine powder. The toasting, as mentioned in other recipes, is key to developing flavour and aroma.
- Amchur Powder is not a spice, but a powder made of green mango. It should not be toasted. Opinions differ on this, but - for this recipe, do not toast this ingredient.
- Normally this recipe would be made into a paste with lemon juice and a small amount of water. We use this as a more dry rub, in combination with alread-wet ingredients like potatoes that have been boiled and chickpeas that sit in "aqua fava" (literally: bean water).
- If this spice mix is low, talk to a Chef about it. Some of these ingredients come from a specialty provider with an indented delivery schedule - and will need to be ordered several days in advance in order to allow for proper prep time.
Any questions - Ask Chef!

***COOKS AND CHEFS, PLEASE READ THE ENTIRE RECIPE BEFORE BEGINNING- THIS IS A RECOMMENDED STEP WITH EVERY PRODUCT WE EVER PRODUCE- THANK YOU*** Amanda
Related Products this prep gets used in: Allergens: (to be filled out by nutrition) Method:
NOTES: This recipe should be as green as possible - meaning: stewing the green elements of this recipe too far will kill the flavour and visual appeal of the recipe. The idea of this recipe is to have a flavourful earthy base to balance out the fats present in the Paneer (which is to be added last).
Prep:
1. Cut the root ends off of the Green Onions, and then grill them until coloured. Cool, and then chop up in pieces that are no less than 3 inches long.
2. Rough Chop Onions, and begin cooking them out immediately. Throw in Spices(toast spices) Garlic, and Ginger. Deglaze with veg stock. Season and simmer for 5-10 minutes.
3. Cut Paneer into bite-sized cubes - nothing too big. It will cut like Tofu, but it will also flake off..
4. Add HALF of the Spinach in the recipe, and cover for 5 minutes. You want the Spinach to be cooked out, but not to the point of bitterness. At this point, the recipe is very close to being taken off heat.
5. Add the Cilantro. Then, using an Immersion Blender, puree the Spinach and its juices into a sauce. This does not have to be a uniform puree as it would come out of a Vitamix - a little bit of texture is OK. Taste & check for seasoning.
6. Add Chopped Green Onions (grilled), Paneer, the other half of the Spinach, and the Cilantro - season again to taste using the salt in this recipe. Turn off heat.
7. Add Yogurt before moving this recipe intoserving pans. Reserve for service.
*Cool, store, label and rotate this item with older product correctly and diligently

Method:

ALLERGENS: MUSTARD
Notes: This recipe is all about timing. It can easily be done on the side, without hassle, while other recipes are in development. There are key areas that require direct supervision - the rest can be managed by raising or lowering heat, and intelligently employing different equipment to serve different functions throughout the recipe.
Prep:
- Turn on the Tilt Skillet - as high as it will go.
- Soak Yellow Split Peas overnight. Soak in a stock if possible. IF you soak in a stock, place the stock and the split peas in a couple of shallow trays and throw them in the steamer. Ideal cook time: 2 Hours.
- Have your onions ready, as well as your 5 Spice Mix, and your Ginger and Garlic - BEFORE YOU ADD OIL TO THE TILT SKILLET. Add oil, and immediately put your onions in there. You might want to even add some water to avoid burning if you have too much going on at once. Drop the temperature of the skillet to 350F/180C, and let simmer (if you added water), until there is almost no moisture left.
- Add your 5 Spice and Garam Masala, and saute out thoroughly. Rememeber there is blitz'd up Yellow Split Peas in the 5 Spice itself, so it needs toasting. After this, add your Butternut Squash, and deglaze with your water. You may need to add more water to this recipe - 10L should be considered the minimum.
- Raise the temperature of the skillet if you need to now, to make sure that you're boiling your Butternut Squash. It will take about 30-40 minutes to cook out depending on circumstances. Add your curry leaves, and Sprouted Pulses. Reserve Green Onions, Cilantro, and Kale until last for your Coconut Milk finish.
- At this point, check your Yellow Split Peas. They need to be done. They will likely be "al dente", but that's OK. Add them to the mixture, and cook them with the Squash. They are now your indicator as to how you're doing - the Squash may finish before the Split Peas.
- Season to taste. Add Coconut Milk VERY LAST, along with Cilantro and Green Onions. Check Seasoning.
Any questions? Ask Chef...

For stocks - save all your parsley, leek, green onion and cilantro ends!!!!!!
1. Sautee onion, garlic and leek. Cook out for 5 minuts untill soft.
2. Add carrot, celery and the spices and sautee for a few more minutes.
3. Add water and bring to a boil, turn down to a low simmer and let it ride for 45 minutes.
4. Turn off the burner and throw in the parsley and leek ends and let the stock sit for another 30 minutes with the heat off.
5. Strain, downsize and cool down.

1.Remove the leafs from the thick stems, discard stems
2. Using a sharp chef knife place the leaves together and lightly roll together
3. Using a slicing motion mince the mint into thin strips (chiffanade) turn the other way and repeat until mint is rough chopped. Always use a slicing motion rather than a chopping motion on soft herbs to prevent bruising.
4. Store in an apropriate sice insert/container with a piece of paper towel at the bottom to wick away any moisture.

PREP RECIPE
Remove the skin form the chicken and slash the chicken meat down to the bone in a couple places per leg.
Combine and mix chicken with the other ingredients in order to marinate.

Related Products this prep gets used in:
Allergens: (to be filled out by nutrition) Method:
1. Heat a large pot over medium heat. Once hot, add oil, onion, cumin, and one-third of the salt.(Adjust if altering batch size).
2. Add garlic, ginger, cilantro, and green chilies to Robot coupe to pulse into a paste. Then, add to the pan with the onions.
3. Next add ground coriander, chili powder, and turmeric and stir to coat. Add a little more oil at this point if the pan is looking dry.
4. Next add pureed tomatoes and chickpeas and remaining salt. If the mixture looks a little too thick, add up to 1 cup (250 ml) water. You’re looking for a semi-thick soup consistency at this point, as it will cook down into more of a stew.
5. Increase heat to medium high until it reaches a rolling simmer, then reduce heat to low or medium-low and maintain a simmer (uncovered) for 15-20 minutes, or until thick and stew-like. Stir occasionally.
6. When the chana masala is thickened and bubbly, taste and adjust seasonings as needed, add more salt if needed.
7. Remove from heat and add lemon juice and garam masala. Stir to mix.
Hot hold/serve immediately
*Cool, store, label and rotate this item with older product correctly and diligently

Related Products this prep gets used in:
Method:
1.Rinse the lentils in cold water until the water runs clear.
2.Heat a large Rondeau or tilt skillet over medium-high heat and add the oil. Once the oil is shimmering, add the garlic, ginger, and Serrano pepper and cook for 2 minutes, stirring frequently to prevent garlic from burning.
3. Add the cumin, coriander, chili powder, curry powder, garam masala, salt, and black pepper to taste, and cook for 30 to 60 seconds until fragrant, tossing frequently to prevent burning. Add the ground turmeric now, along the the rest of the spices.
4. Pour in the vegetable broth, and use a wooden spoon or spatula to scrape up any browned bits on the bottom of the pot. Add in the lentils and the crushed tomatoes and mix well.
5. Reduce the heat to low and cover the pan with a lid. Simmer for 20 to 25 minutes, or until the lentils are cooked through and have mostly softened. If you find that the lentils are not quite soft after 25 minutes, add a bit more veg stock and cook for another 5 minutes.
6. Remove the lid and stir in the coconut milk.
7. Continue cooking on low heat, uncovered for 5 to 8 minutes, until the curry has thickened and is creamy.
8. Finally, stir in the lemon juice and cilantro, and turn off the heat.
9. Reserve for service.
*Cool, store, label and rotate this item with older product correctly and diligently

***COOKS AND CHEFS, PLEASE READ THE ENTIRE RECIPE BEFORE BEGINNING- THIS IS A RECOMMENDED STEP WITH EVERY PRODUCT WE EVER PRODUCE- THANK YOU*** Amanda
Related Products this prep gets used in:
Method:
1. Heat 1/2 of the oil in a large rondeau. Fry potatoes in hot oil until brown. Remove to a paper towel-lined tray to drain and reserve.
2. Add remaining oil to the rondeau and fry onions, garlic, and fresh ginger until onion is soft and golden. Add chili, pepper, turmeric, cumin, salt, and tomatoes. Fry, stirring constantly, for 5 minutes. Stir in yogurt, mint, ground cardamom, and cinnamon stick. Cover and cook over low heat, stirring occasionally, until the tomatoes are cooked to a pulp. It may be necessary to add a little hot water if the mixture becomes too dry and starts to stick to the pan.
3. When mixture is thick and smooth, add chicken and stir well to coat. Cover and cook over very low heat until chicken is tender, 30 to 35 minutes. There should only be a little very thick sauce left when the chicken is finished cooking. If necessary cook uncovered for a few minutes to reduce the sauce.
RICE:
1. Wash rice well and drain well for at least 30 minutes.
2. Heat remaining oil in a large rondeau. Fry onion in hot oil until golden. Add saffron, cardamom pods, cloves, cinnamon stick, ground ginger, and rice. Stir continuously until rice is coated with spices.
3. Heat stock and salt in a pot. When the mixture is hot, pour it over the rice and stir well. Add the chicken mixture and quartered potatoes; gently mix them into the rice. Bring to boil. Cover the saucepan tightly, turn heat to very low, and steam for 20 minutes. Do not lift lid or stir while cooking!
*Cool, store, label and rotate this item with older product correctly and diligently

Method:
1. In a large bowl, combine yogurt, lemon juice, cumin, cinnamon, cayenne, black pepper, ginger, and salt. Stir in chicken, cover, and refrigerate for 1 hour.
2. In a 400F oven place chicken on parchment lined sheet trays and roast just untill cooked (10-12 minutes apporox) Reserve.
3. Melt butter in a large rondeau over medium heat. Saute garlic and finely minced serrano pepper for 1 minute. Season with cumin, paprika, and salt. Stir in crushed tomatoes and cream. Simmer on low heat until sauce thickens, about 20 minutes.
4. Add roasted chicken, and simmer for 10 minutes. Remove from heat and stir in fresh cilantro.
5. Reserve for service.
*Cool, store, label and rotate this item with older product correctly and diligently

***COOKS AND CHEFS, PLEASE READ THE ENTIRE RECIPE BEFORE BEGINNING- THIS IS A RECOMMENDED STEP WITH EVERY PRODUCT WE EVER PRODUCE- THANK YOU*** Amanda
Related Products this prep gets used in:
Method:
MARINATE THE CHICKEN
1. Put the chicken in a large bowl with the yogurt, turmeric and pinch of salt. Mix well. Chill for 2 hours, or preferably overnight.
CASHEW PASTE
2. Put 80g of cashews into a Vitamix, along with 110ml of hot water, ginger, and serrano peppers. Blitz to a smooth paste and reserve.
COOK THE CHICKEN
3. Heat the oil in a large rondeau over a medium heat, and sizzle the cinnamon and clove for 1 minute.
4. Add the onion and fry, stirring for 10-12 minutes until softened and turning golden brown. Add the chicken and left-over marinade and fry for 8 minutes, turning the chicken to seal as you go. Reduce the heat.
5. Add 100ml of water, cover and cook for 25 minutes, stirring halfway through.
6. Add the cashew paste, remove the lid and simmer for 5-7 minutes, or until the gravy has thickened slightly and just coats the chicken. Add the cardamom powder, stir into sauce and chicken. Cover and turn off the heat. let sit 5 minutes.
7. Heat the oil in a small pan. Fry the remaining cashews for 2-3 minutes or until starting to brown (DO NOT WALK AWAY DURING THIS PROCESS) Scoop into a bowl with a slotted spoon. Set aside. Add the mustard seeds and curry leaves to the pan. As soon as they begin to splutter, pour everything over the chicken, along with the cashew nuts. Ready to serve!
*Cool, store, label and rotate this item with older product correctly and diligently

Related Products this prep gets used in:
Method:
1. Cook the cumin seeds, cloves, cardamom pods, ground almonds, coconut and sesame seeds in a small pan for 2-3 minutes or until lightly toasted. Cool, then use a spice grinder to grind to a powder.
2. Put the ginger, garlic, serrano chillies and 60ml water into a food processor and blend to a purée. Stir into the spice powder.
3. Heat the oil in a large rondeau and fry the potatoes for 10 minutes until really golden all over. Add the onions and fry for 5 minutes until soft and golden.
4. Add in the purée along salt & pepper, the ground turmeric, yogurt and 300ml of water. Mix well, put on a lid and simmer for 20 minutes or until the potatoes are just tender. Remove the lid and simmer for another 10-15 minutes or until the sauce has thickened.
5. Taste for seasoning, adjust as needed. Add Chopped cilantro and fold in.
*Cool, store, label and rotate this item with older product correctly and diligently

Method:
1. Heat 1/2 of the oil in a large rondeau. Fry potatoes in hot oil until brown. Remove to a paper towel-lined tray to drain and reserve.
2. Add remaining oil to the rondeau and fry onions, garlic, and fresh ginger until onion is soft and golden. Add chili, pepper, turmeric, cumin, salt, and tomatoes. Fry, stirring constantly, for 5 minutes. Stir in yogurt, mint, ground cardamom, and cinnamon stick. Cover and cook over low heat, stirring occasionally, until the tomatoes are cooked to a pulp. It may be necessary to add a little hot water if the mixture becomes too dry and starts to stick to the pan.
3. When mixture is thick and smooth, add Tofu and stir well to coat. Cover and cook over very low heat, 20 to 30 minutes. There should only be a little very thick sauce left when the biryani is finished cooking. If necessary cook uncovered for a few minutes to reduce the sauce.
RICE:
1. Wash rice well and drain well for at least 30 minutes.
2. Heat remaining oil in a large rondeau. Fry onion in hot oil until golden. Add saffron, cardamom pods, cloves, cinnamon stick, ground ginger, and rice. Stir continuously until rice is coated with spices.
3. Heat stock and salt in a pot. When the mixture is hot, pour it over the rice and stir well. Add the chicken mixture and quartered potatoes; gently mix them into the rice. Bring to boil. Cover the saucepan tightly, turn heat to very low, and steam for 20 minutes. Do not lift lid or stir while cooking!
